overview: Current practices of urban and regional planning have emerged as a human response to the range of circumstances surrounding settlements over time. This subject provides students with a grounding in the main theories of planning over the last two centuries as a means of understanding present-day planning practices and debates in an historical context. Accordingly, students will develop understandings of the contexts in which planning emerged as a response to concerns with a range of circumstances over time. These include: public health, technological change, environmental degradation, economic development, social justice, and conceptions of order and aesthetics. An integrated programme of lectures, readings and tutorials provide students with the materials to answer a series of related questions that chart the development over time of planning. The evolving responses to the enduring questions of planning, such as: ‘what is planning; why plan; how to plan; and what or for whom do we plan?’ are charted over time. The Australia response, in an international context, is emphasised to provide a critical lens upon current Australian planning, providing a basis for subsequent subjects in the Masters of Urban Planning Program.
ilo: Describe major themes in past and present urban planning, and contextualise major theories influencing urban planning internationally and in Australia;
Critically analyse ideas about planning in the light of current practice;
Use contemporary planning terms and expression to discuss, present and write coherently about  debates and themes of planning.
generic_skills: Ability to analyse social and cultural contexts;
Critical evaluation of policies and practices.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Three  tutorial papers, due weeks  3, 6 and 9

date_times.contact_hours: 3 hours per week (1 x 2-hour lecture + 1 x 1-hour tutorial)
